Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: Three-Dimensional Simulations of Type Ia Supernovae: Constraining Models with Observations
Award.AbstractNarration:
AST-0709181/AST-0707704/AST-0708873/AST-0708855
Kohkhlov/Baron/Wang/Hoeflich

This project is a comprehensive theoretical analysis of thermonuclear Type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia), which will account for any three-dimensional (3D) processes affecting SNe Ia explosions, and will provide a rigorous comparison of model predictions with existing and future high quality observations. The methods and techniques will be combined into the remote-access SNe Ia computational pipeline, which comprises sophisticated 3D simulation algorithms for fluid dynamics, nucleosynthesis, and radiation transport, as well as tools for the 3D analysis of SNe Ia data. SNe Ia are crucial for identifying the nature of dark energy, one of the most important problems facing modern science, because they serve as one of the most direct and precise distance indicators in the Universe. The results of this study will improve the cosmological calibration of these critical tools, by trying to understand what affects their status as standard candles, notably the different types of progenitor systems, deviations from spherical symmetry, and interaction with circumstellar matter. One important outcome will be a comprehensive set of observationally verified first-principles multidimensional explosion models of SNe Ia. Identifying physical correlations among predicted and observed signatures of SNe Ia will be crucial for improving the accuracy of their calibration.

This work is an exceptional platform for introducing students to cross-disciplinary and multi-field science, through the many areas involved in studying SNe Ia, such as numerical methods, large-scale hydrodynamics and radiation transport simulations, observations, and cosmological applications. Research results will be made available to the broad scientific community via the developed computational pipeline, and will be disseminated to the wider non-technical audience. The results will also benefit current and future ground- and space-based observing programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A Type 1a supernova is a thermonuclear stellar explosion that releases vast amounts of energy in a few seconds. During the explosion some of the energy is used to create highly radioactive heavy elements. In the days following the initial explosion, the radioactive decay of these elements heats up the material ejected by the explosion and a very bright ?star? appears in the sky. Because this brightness can be comparable to that of a whole galaxy, supernovae can be seen over great distances. By comparing the real brightness of the supernova to the brightness measured here on Earth it is possible to determine the distance to the supernova and hence the distance of the host galaxy. For this reason, Type 1a supernovae are the ?standard candles? routinely used to measure cosmic distances.

The real brightness, however, is not known; the trick is to be able to reconstruct it from the observations of the aftermath of the explosion. This requires being able to compute the energy released by the explosion.

Type 1a supernovae consist of a thermonuclear flame burning though the star; the propagation properties of the flame determine both the rate at which energy is released and how much radioactive elements are produced. Thus, in order to determine cosmic scales to high precision it is crucial to be able accurately to describe the propagation of flame fronts through the stellar interior. There are many factors that can affect flame propagation: the nature of the nuclear fuel, the physical conditions like temperature and density, the internal structure of the star, and in some cases, if the progenitor star is magnetized, the presence of magnetic fields.

In this study we considered precisely this problem: how the propagation of a nuclear flame in a stellar interior is affected by the presence of magnetic fields. Because magnetic fields have both a magnitude and a direction (they are vectors) the effects depend on both the field strength and on the field geometry. The results of our study have shown that in many circumstances magnetic fields can have a substantial effect on flame propagation, both by speeding up the flame and slowing it down depending on the direction of the field relative to the direction of the flame front. Incorporating these magnetic effects in the models of Type 1a supernovae calculations will give better estimates of the energy produced by the stellar explosion and, ultimately, more accurate measurements of cosmic distances.
